{
  "triples": [
    {
      "s": "Taylor expansion",
      "p": "represents",
      "o": "approximation of smooth, well-behaved functions",
      "modalities": ["text"],
      "confidence": 0.9,
      "evidence": "This allows us to approximate any smooth, well-behaved function using a sum of terms"
    },
    {
      "s": "Taylor expansion",
      "p": "uses",
      "o": "constant, linear, quadratic terms",
      "modalities": ["text"],
      "confidence": 0.9,
      "evidence": "starting with a constant (the function’s value at a point), then adding linear terms based on the first derivative, and quadratic terms based on the second derivative, and so on."
    },
    {
      "s": "engineering practice",
      "p": "uses",
      "o": "simpler terms",
      "modalities": ["text"],
      "confidence": 0.9,
      "evidence": "In engineering practice, though, we often stop at the simpler terms—constant or linear—because they offer a good balance of accuracy and simplicity."
    }

evidence: In engineering practice, though, we often stop at the simpler terms-constant or linear-because they offer a good balance of accuracy and simplicity.
